item.title: Poincaré's unpredictable determinism
item.description: Poincaré showed that the three-body problem (gravitation) cannot be analytically solved. Non-observable continuous fluctuations (below any physical instrument precision) can be amplified non-linearly.

item.title: Anfinsen's dogma
item.description: It is an postulate for the protein folding problem. The native structure of proteins in the physiological environement is solely determined by the amino acid sequence.

item.title: protein folding problem
item.description: How does a protein folds ? Levinthal’s paradox states that if the protein tries all configurations, it will take forever. However, it does fold.

item.title: Brillouin's relation between entropy and information
item.description: In 1951, Brilliouin related information and entropy to resolve Maxwell’s demon paradox; more precisely Shannon’s theory of information transmission and the second principle of thermodynamics.

item.title: computability
item.description: Three notions of computability are equivalent: The existence of a Turing machine for computing the function. The abacus-computability. A recursive function.

item.title: Crick's central dogma
item.description: It postulates that proteins never transmit “sequential information”. “Sequential information” is to be understood as the sequence of bases in DNA or amino-acids in proteins.

item.title: Laplacian determinism
item.description: A demiurge could predict the future with solely position and velocity of all particles in the universe. Laplace states that any deterministic system is therefore predictable.

item.title: Maxwell's demon paradox
item.description: It was suggested in 1867 by Maxwell. A ‘finite being’ can open or close a door between two boxes. Depending on the velocity of the particle that is coming close to the door, he lets fast particles go to one side and slow ones on the other side.

item.title: negentropy
item.description: First mentionned in Schrodinger1944 to characterize living systems, it is rigourously introduced by Brillouin1951 to relate it to the opposite of entropy and positively to information (see Brillouin’s relation between entropy and information).

item.title: Schrödinger's code-script aperiodic crystal
item.description: In 1944, Schrödinger imagine that a “code-script” could be found in “aperiodic crystals” (chromosomes) of living systems ( Schrodinger1944). Without mentionning “information”, it does refer to a discrete encoding and therefore implies Laplacian determinism (and predictability).

item.title: second principle of thermodynamic
item.description: The entropy of a closed system with fixed volume can only increase. It is maximum at equilibrium for a system at constant energy.

item.title: Shannon's theory of information transmission
item.description: Be $X$ a random variable with $X\in{x_1,x_2,…,x_n}$ and $p_i=\mathbb{P}(X=x_i)$. Shannon relates the amount of information of one string to the amount of surprise of seeing it.

item.title: Turing machine
item.description: In 1936, Turing introduces the idea of a “computing machine”, latter called “Turing machine”. He pictures not a mecanism but a person — “Turing’s architect” according to ( Schrodinger1944) Turing introduced ( Turing1936) this machine trying to answer questions regarding decidability.

item.title: Cantor's diagonal argument
item.description: One of Cantor’s theorem is that the set of all sets of natural numbers is not enumerable. The set of real numbers is the set of all set of natural numbers because you form a real number by precising its decimals.

item.title: Church-Turing thesis
item.description: An arithmetic function is effectively computable if and only if it is computable (see computability). This is a thesis because it is not provable because it refers to the informal effectively computable notion.

item.title: effectively computable

item.title: halting problem
item.description: Given a Turing machine and an initial binary strings, the problem consists in knowing if it will halt or not. This problem cannot be solve because the halting function is not computable (see computability).
